description: From Middle English rejoicen, rejoisen, from Old French resjoir. Compare also English rejoy.

verbs.description: rejoice (third-person singular simple present rejoices, present participle rejoicing, simple past and past participle rejoiced)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be very happy, be delighted, exult; to feel joy. [from 14th c.]
examples: Obscurity, indeed, is painful to the mind as well as to the eye ; but to bring light from obscurity, by whatever labour, must needs to be delightful and rejoicing.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To have (someone) as a lover or spouse; to enjoy sexually. [15th–16th c.]

examples: But good news awaited them in the form of permission to travel about the area replenishing medical stocks in hospitals and clinics, and this task was delegated to Constance, as the newcomer, a fact which rejoiced her.
his brother Constans next aftir him rejoiced the same west-parti.
